Key Match Events: Aaron Judge and Jazz Chisholm Jr. hit back-to-back homers in the bottom of the first for a 3-0 lead, which increased to 4-0 in the second and 5-0 in the third.
A sloppy defensive showing by New York in the fifth inning gave the Dodgers their first scores, eventually tying the game.
A sacrifice fly from Giancarlo Stanton in the bottom of the sixth saw Juan Soto reach home for New York to take a 6-5 lead, but L.A. came back in the top of the eighth and didn't look back.
Star starter Walker Buehler entered in the ninth inning and retired the Yankees in order to close it out for L.A.
A sacrifice fly from Mookie Betts in the bottom of the eighth gave the Dodgers a 7-6 lead, and Buehler secured the win in the ninth.
Post-Match Reflections: Aaron Judge expressed pride in the team's resilience after the comeback win.
The coach highlighted the victory as a pivotal moment in their playoff push.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Yankees' catastrophic defense in the fifth inning made history, becoming the only MLB team to blow a 5+ run lead, allow 5+ unearned runs, commit 3+ errors, commit catcher's interference, and commit a balk in the same game since earned runs became an official stat in 1913.
The game went into 15 innings before a decisive home run by Mookie Betts.
Others: The Dodgers won their eighth World Series and first since 2020, while the Yankees' drought since 2009 persisted.
The Yankees avoided a sweep against the Los Angeles Dodgers, but couldn't force the series back to the opposite coast.

The Dodgers gave the nod to veteran righty Jack Flaherty, but he was pulled in the second inning as Dave Roberts shuffled between his bullpen again, eventually ending with star starter Walker Buehler closing it out.
